summary: The fact that Daenerys had goodness in her doesn’t mean it wasn’t foreshadowed that she was going mad. Was she properly...
body: The fact that Daenerys had goodness in her doesn’t mean it wasn’t foreshadowed that she was going mad. Was she properly developed into someone that went mad? No. But it was foreshadowed.

reblog.comment: The fact that Daenerys had goodness in her doesn’t mean it wasn’t foreshadowed that she was going mad. Was she properly developed into someone that went mad? No. But it was foreshadowed.

trail.content_raw: The fact that Daenerys had goodness in her doesn’t mean it wasn’t foreshadowed that she was going mad. Was she properly developed into someone that went mad? No. But it was foreshadowed.
trail.content: The fact that Daenerys had goodness in her doesn’t mean it wasn’t foreshadowed that she was going mad. Was she properly developed into someone that went mad? No. But it was foreshadowed.

blog.name: lodessa
blog.title: Not a Smut Queen... A Smut Khaleesi
blog.description:
I appear to have tumbled back down into Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire Fandom again (Jaime/Brienne, Dany/Jorah, Jon/Sansa, amongst other pairings). I'm still living that Star Trek Fan Life (mostly Voyager [Janeway/Chakotay OTP) and Discovery (Admiral Katrina Cornwell and Captain Philippa Georgiou focus). I cannot possibly list everything I might reblog, but forever carrying a torch for Veronica Mars (I live a Weevil appreciation life), Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries, Doctor Who (Nine, Martha Jones), Roslin/Adama, Buffy/Faith, Aral/Cordelia, amongst others.


Testimonial by wakeupgreat:

"lodessa is an amazing human! she can be recognized in the wild by her inara icon and is known across the land for star trek rpf and for being into a song of ice and fire long before it was a tv show. she is a fellow fandom oldie and we relate on many levels. also once she wrote me cersei/brienne so basically she is the BEST."

summary: So I was going back and forth with @scratchybeardsweetmouth in the comments of A Bane of the Heart, and realized that basically...
body:
So I was going back and forth with @scratchybeardsweetmouth in the comments of A Bane of the Heart, and realized that basically the Dany/Jorah meta we were discussing was something that I wanted to articulate outside of that setting.

We started out talking about my choice to have Jorah not question his understanding about where he stands with her, that she’s not interested in him romantically, based on the hints to the contrary she’s giving off through the fic, and thus be completely taken by surprise when she straight up tells him otherwise.

My rationale was that Jorah would have a hard time interpreting Dany’s change in approach towards him partly because he truly accepted the prior status quo, but honestly more so because it isn’t really “new” the way she is reacting to him in the fic. Like she was in denial about her heart eyes before but that doesn’t mean she wasn’t making them, so he’s been persuaded that isn’t evidence or even a hint of her being romantically interested in him… when really it is just that she wasn’t conscious of how that has been there under the surface for her for a long time. So he’s like “Not going to misread this totally platonic gazing Khaleesi is doing. Nope. I will just be grateful that she is seemingly happy to be in my company again. This foolish old bear knows better.”

@scratchybeardsweetmouth brought up the books, saying:

 “I know his book version is not popular and I understand that, but it is in some ways the similar kind of affections she showed him that he thought she reciprocated his feelings and so he took his chance by kissing her. And so when she expressed that she didn’t desire him and then was banished later on, there is this realization that just being by her side and serving her was enough for him and so he does not want to destroy his precious bond with her, especially if she gives him a chance to stand by her again. With this fic that eventually plays out she did have feelings for him, it feels so real that denial on his part would be expected.”

Which is what triggered the real heart of this meta: 

There’s a lot of reasons that the show vs book versions of them feel really different to me, and some of them are adaptation choices, but I think part of it is straight up the difference of medium. In the books, we are in Dany’s head. We see through her eyes and feel through her emotions. So we know what her actions mean to her, how she sees him, and we anticipate her reactions. In a show, we see both of them from an outside perspective, watching their actions, body language, and expression… listening to words and tone. And I don’t know how intentional exactly the way those come off was, but it’s very real and from the perspective of viewing the show and seeing/hearing her interact with him from the outside… I can understand why he would hold that hope. I suppose that I would probably have read their dynamic very differently than I did originally if you read their interactions from Jorah’s POV instead of Dany’s for exactly these reasons.

Also, the fact that he reconciles his feelings and accepts what is instead of what he wanted to see… is a huge part of what makes them shippable for me. Like that’s the moment where his love for her actually deepens into something more substantial really. Because it isn’t transactional. It isn’t based on expecting or seeking something out of it. He just loves her and wants to be there with/for her in the ways she is available for. Not because he doesn’t still want her, but because it doesn’t matter if she doesn’t (in terms of his feelings, not in terms of not caring about her wants).

@scratchybeardsweetmouth added:

“The difference in mediums allows us to see their interactions in the show without the internal monologue, and so it leaves us to take them for what they are, which already are telling us so much because of their acting. That said, I wouldn’t mind a Jorah POV just once in future books.

Everything about the second paragraph makes me nod and smile, especially "Because it isn’t transactional.” I think for me it went back to the first funeral pyre scene - where I began to root for them - where he simply wanted her to choose to live, thinking that she’ll be sacrificing her life to join her husband. Others might say he needed her to survive for the contract with Varys or that she is his ticket to Westeros. But he never stopped her as she walked into the flames after she promised him self-sacrifice isn’t the goal. He trusted her and loved her that he wanted her to live to see that even with painful losses, life is still worth living.”

(*heavy breathing* I WOULD CERTAINLY NOT MIND A JORAH POV.)

I can’t even pinpoint the moment in the show where I started shipping them (I, like Daenerys was perhaps in denial about my feelings for a long time).

But that scene is so incredibly powerful. It’s so pure. I truly believe that he meant everything he said there, and you know she did too. (The idea that he, at that point, was still there for a “deal” feels very intentionally and unnecessarily negative and cynical… he’d already had a chance to go home and he chose her over it!) He chooses to believe in her there, to discard his cynicism and stand aside and allow her step into becoming a legend. He could have dragged her away from that pyre, and the truth is that she would have forgiven him. She would never have really known what she lost and she would have known that he was protecting her as best he could. But instead he trusts her and stands by her choice and watches her ascend to the level of myths.

A lot happens after this point: her discovery that he was initially spying on her for Robert’s small council, his banishment, Tyrion’s input, everything that happens with Daario and Jon, Jorah’s greyscale.  All of it important and worthy of discussion, of course, but perhaps not as important as the way her face lights up for Jorah alone.

We started out talking about my choice to have Jorah not question his understanding about where he stands with her, that she’s not interested in him romantically, based on the hints to the contrary she’s giving off through the fic, and thus be completely taken by surprise when she straight up tells him otherwise.

My rationale was that Jorah would have a hard time interpreting Dany’s change in approach towards him partly because he truly accepted the prior status quo, but honestly more so because it isn’t really “new” the way she is reacting to him in the fic. Like she was in denial about her heart eyes before but that doesn’t mean she wasn’t making them, so he’s been persuaded that isn’t evidence or even a hint of her being romantically interested in him… when really it is just that she wasn’t conscious of how that has been there under the surface for her for a long time. So he’s like “Not going to misread this totally platonic gazing Khaleesi is doing. Nope. I will just be grateful that she is seemingly happy to be in my company again. This foolish old bear knows better.”

@scratchybeardsweetmouth brought up the books, saying:

 “I know his book version is not popular and I understand that, but it is in some ways the similar kind of affections she showed him that he thought she reciprocated his feelings and so he took his chance by kissing her. And so when she expressed that she didn’t desire him and then was banished later on, there is this realization that just being by her side and serving her was enough for him and so he does not want to destroy his precious bond with her, especially if she gives him a chance to stand by her again. With this fic that eventually plays out she did have feelings for him, it feels so real that denial on his part would be expected.”

There’s a lot of reasons that the show vs book versions of them feel really different to me, and some of them are adaptation choices, but I think part of it is straight up the difference of medium. And I don’t know how intentional exactly the way those come off was, but it’s very real and from the perspective of viewing the show and seeing/hearing her interact with him from the outside… I can understand why he would hold that hope. I suppose that I would probably have read their dynamic very differently than I did originally if you read their interactions from Jorah’s POV instead of Dany’s for exactly these reasons.

Others might say he needed her to survive for the contract with Varys or that she is his ticket to Westeros. But he never stopped her as she walked into the flames after she promised him self-sacrifice isn’t the goal. He trusted her and loved her that he wanted her to live to see that even with painful losses, life is still worth living.”

But that scene is so incredibly powerful. It’s so pure. I truly believe that he meant everything he said there, and you know she did too. (The idea that he, at that point, was still there for a “deal” feels very intentionally and unnecessarily negative and cynical… he’d already had a chance to go home and he chose her over it!) He chooses to believe in her there, to discard his cynicism and stand aside and allow her step into becoming a legend. But instead he trusts her and stands by her choice and watches her ascend to the level of myths.

blog.name: ladyofdragonstone

blog.description: Film student | 20 | She/Her | My Ao3 | Fanart | Inbox always open | DO NOT GO GENTLE INTO THAT [LONG] NIGHT | Anti GoT |

summary: If Jonerys doesn't happen in the books, what will be your reaction? Btw I love your blog and your art
question: If Jonerys doesn't happen in the books, what will be your reaction? Btw I love your blog and your art
answer:
Thank you for the praise

For a couple that haven’t so much as heard of each other yet, a Jon and Dany romance has been built up entirely too much not to occur. 

Whether that romance ends well is what is up for interpretation and debate. I have always speculated on the tragicness of their romance, but leaning in poetic self-sacrifice rather than icky betrayal.

I would be unpleasantly shocked if George’s narrative included a mentally unstable Queen, who also happened to be foreign, abused, exiled, barren, and righteous. That would be irresponsible social commentary, yet I’m relieved to say that’s not where GRRM is going: In ASOIAF, the main protagonists will struggle to break out of the predisposed paths that family, genetics, and society have set down for them, even if they stray off, they can still change and grow and be better. 

And there is the (quite literally) other problem in this “Dany is the ultimate villain” narrative, which is: The real enemy is the cold. Dany is part of the fire that burns against the cold, the light that brings the dawn.

I would much rather for Daenerys to redeem herself (yes, I imagine she’ll be in need of some type of redemption by the end of ADOS) by sacrificing every sweet opportunity she’s been given, for love, for rule, for life, in order to end death. If she willingly chooses to fall on Jon’s sword … it will not be sweet, but it cannot be any more repulsive than what HBO attempted.

Thanks for the question, anon xxx

trail.content_raw:
Thank you for the praise

For a couple that haven’t so much as heard of each other yet, a Jon and Dany romance has been built up entirely too much not to occur. 

Whether that romance ends well is what is up for interpretation and debate. I have always speculated on the tragicness of their romance, but leaning in poetic self-sacrifice rather than icky betrayal.

I would be unpleasantly shocked if George’s narrative included a mentally unstable Queen, who also happened to be foreign, abused, exiled, barren, and righteous. That would be irresponsible social commentary, yet I’m relieved to say that’s not where GRRM is going: In ASOIAF, the main protagonists will struggle to break out of the predisposed paths that family, genetics, and society have set down for them, even if they stray off, they can still change and grow and be better. 

And there is the (quite literally) other problem in this “Dany is the ultimate villain” narrative, which is: The real enemy is the cold. Dany is part of the fire that burns against the cold, the light that brings the dawn.

I would much rather for Daenerys to redeem herself (yes, I imagine she’ll be in need of some type of redemption by the end of ADOS) by sacrificing every sweet opportunity she’s been given, for love, for rule, for life, in order to end death. If she willingly chooses to fall on Jon’s sword … it will not be sweet, but it cannot be any more repulsive than what HBO attempted.

Thanks for the question, anon xxx
trail.content:
Thank you for the praise

For a couple that haven’t so much as heard of each other yet, a Jon and Dany romance has been built up entirely too much not to occur. 

Whether that romance ends well is what is up for interpretation and debate. I have always speculated on the tragicness of their romance, but leaning in poetic self-sacrifice rather than icky betrayal.

I would be unpleasantly shocked if George’s narrative included a mentally unstable Queen, who also happened to be foreign, abused, exiled, barren, and righteous. That would be irresponsible social commentary, yet I’m relieved to say that’s not where GRRM is going: In ASOIAF, the main protagonists will struggle to break out of the predisposed paths that family, genetics, and society have set down for them, even if they stray off, they can still change and grow and be better. 

And there is the (quite literally) other problem in this “Dany is the ultimate villain” narrative, which is: The real enemy is the cold. Dany is part of the fire that burns against the cold, the light that brings the dawn.

I would much rather for Daenerys to redeem herself (yes, I imagine she’ll be in need of some type of redemption by the end of ADOS) by sacrificing every sweet opportunity she’s been given, for love, for rule, for life, in order to end death. If she willingly chooses to fall on Jon’s sword … it will not be sweet, but it cannot be any more repulsive than what HBO attempted.

Thanks for the question, anon xxx

and I’m always staring at his proudly bulging junk. /
Hell yeah, you’re everything I want and have ever dreamed about in a man, /
just one gaze from your heavenly bright heart eyes /
takes my breath away! //"

Are we still fighting about ships? After all this? REALLY?

Jon stabbed through the heat 3-4 times: mumbles fuck Olly....
body:
Ygritte shot through the heart: manages to insult Jon one last time.

Jon stabbed through the heat 3-4 times: mumbles fuck Olly.

Tywin Lannister shot through the heart: writes a 10 page essay on how Tyrion is not his son.

Daenerys stabbed through the heart: dies instantly
